How to Twine Your Note Into a Webpage

18 Jan 2016

Today, I am going to introduce you to this amazing tool called Twine

  • Whole video tutorial
  • Introduction
  • Building your first project
    • The two basic syntaxes to remember
  • Adding a Home button
  • Adding images
  • publish your work
  • Ending
    • tips

Whole video tutorial

Introduction

Twine is an open-source tool for telling interactive, nonlinear stories. It was developed by Chris Klimas back in 2009.

And the good news is that you don’t need any expert experience with software or web development in order to Twine!

So, what exactly can Twine help you? I think its power has no boundary.

Let’s go through an example to illusrate what Twine can do.

Click here to see the example demo video.

Building your first project

Ok, let’s start building a very simple project to illustrate the workflow of Twine.

Before I walk you through the nitty gritty, let’s make sure that *you have Twine downloaded. Download Twine here *And you have a Dropbox account setup. *You can also download the Twine template file My first trial here

The two basic syntaxes to remember

To build this project, you only need to remember two syntaxes below.

[[]] ##

You can see the demo video for building a simple project from here

Adding a Home button

See video demo here

Adding images

After mastering some basic text editing skill with TWINE, it is time to consider adding some images to your webpage. To do that, all you need to remember is the following html image tag

<img src="image url">

Click here to the video demo for adding image.

publish your work

Now, the last step is to publish your result. The finished product is a html file, you can copy and paste it on your dropbox public folder, and then generate a public link and share it with your friends.

Click here to see a video demo about how to publish your TWINE project.

Ending

Congratulation, I hope you become more interested in web programming and want to explore more with TWINE, I recommand you to subcribe to the channel VegetarianZombie on YouTube which is an amazing video series to walk you through a lot of the details of TWINE or you could read the TWINE documentation to explore more on your own.

tips

I made up a list of tips to share with you to end this tutorial.

  • Use a unique title for every single passage box.
  • Use the same naming convention for all boxes
  • When you use online images, make sure they are not copyright protected.
  • find images that are in similar resolution.
  • push the play button to test the result every now and then, it is always good to debug early.

If you like this tutorial, please share it with your friends, and leave comment.

Good luck.
